channel.title: NPR Morning Edition
channel.description: Morning Edition takes listeners around the country and the world with multi-faceted stories and commentaries every weekday. Hosts Steve Inskeep, Leila Fadel, Michel Martin and A Mart√≠nez bring you the latest breaking news and features to prepare you for the day.

item.title: Corporate America's retreat from DEI has eliminated thousands of jobs
item.description: "I just didn't think it would take this long," one veteran head of diversity, who's been job-hunting since last summer, tells NPR.

item.title: As Trump targets elite schools, Harvard's president says they should 'stand firm'
item.description: Cutting off research funding for Harvard University might hurt the school, its president Alan Garber told NPR, but it also potentially sets back important work that benefits the public.

item.title: Morning news brief
item.description: The latest on the aid situation in Gaza, Harvard's president discusses the university's battle with the Trump administration, corporate America's retreat from DEI has eliminated thousands of jobs.

item.title: President Trump seeks new nuclear deal with Iran
item.description: President Trump said weekend negotiations for a new nuclear deal with Iran were, in his words, "very good." NPR reports on the latest on the talks and what it might take to reach an agreement.

item.title: King Charles visits Canada in show of support for the country's sovereignty
item.description: King Charles' visit to Canada, the first by a British monarch in decades, is being seen as a show of support for its sovereignty after President Trump said he wanted to make Canada the 51st state.

item.title: Experts putting together Revolutionary War-era ship found at World Trade Center site
item.description: Fifteen years ago, archaeologists at the World Trade Center site discovered a ship, deep in the muck, dating back to the Revolutionary War. Now they're putting it back together.

item.title: No hospitals: How war collapsed the health care system of one city
item.description: Before fighting broke out over two years ago, Sudan's capital of Khartoum had nearly 100 public and private medical facilities. Today, not a single one remains operational.

item.title: U.S.-backed group faces criticism as it begins bringing food to Gaza
item.description: A new group backed by the U.S. is beginning to bring food to Gaza. But it is facing growing criticism, and the group's own director has resigned, saying the program is not humanitarian.

item.title: Norwegian Refugee Council's Ahmed Bayram discusses the aid situation in Gaza
item.description: NPR's A Martinez asks Ahmed Bayram, spokesperson for the Norwegian Refugee Council, about the aid situation in Gaza after the resignation of the head of the Gaza Humanitarian Foundation.

item.title: Despite the pause on high tariffs, Chinese factories still face high uncertainty
item.description: A 90-day pause in triple-digit tariffs on Chinese goods has left exporters and importers in a high state of uncertainty.
